Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Long-distance, robust and unobtrusive visual tags for proximal interaction with public display infrastructure
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to dramatically transform the way people interact with and take information away from their physical environments. As information displays and mobile devices continue to multiply, they give access to ever increasing amounts of information. However, limited by their narrow input and output interfaces, personal devices inadvertently isolate their users from their immediate surroundings, instead focusing their attention toward the digital content in the cloud. Natural and effortless interaction could reconnect us to the physical world. Enabling seamless public-private communication has the potential to revolutionize physical display media, outdoor advertising, and public signage. It can generate new interactive experiences which are both immersive and personalized to the user bringing second screen applications beyond dedicated space, such as living room or airplane seat. Furthermore, it can shift digital content delivery from cellular networks to much more granular proximal networks. Going forward, in the advent of wearable camera-enabled devices, such technology can become the primary source of local context and intent information, relieving the user from the task of manual or vocal input. It will become the essential stepping stone as information services move from ?request? to a more powerful ?suggest? mode.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop visual tags which can be scanned from afar while remaining visually unobtrusive. Visual barcodes trade small size, large decoding distance, and robustness. The proposed technology overcomes this trade-off by re-evaluating the characteristics of the usage scenario and fundamentally reorganizing the object-scanner relationship. This research will result in a practical system design which shifts considerable complexity from the scanner to the infrastructure. With lower complexity, the visual tags can be decoded quickly, robustly, and at distances beyond the reach of 2D barcodes. Additionally, by leveraging a novel spatio-temporal display technique, called VRCodes, the proposed visual tags are essentially imperceptible. This research will advance this technique to use no dedicated visual real estate. A side outcome of this work is a better understanding for how much information can be transmitted through the visible light channel unbeknownst to the end viewer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The human eye and brain do not see in the same way that the cameras on our mobile devices do. 
This NSF SBIR I grant enabled PIXELSIO to identify and quantify the ways we see as relevant to 
the development of (i) unobtrusive (ii) machine-decodable digital overlays for (iii) ordinary display 
screens and cameras. The understanding and methods developed in this phase enable us to make 
our initial demo scalable for use in a wide range of off-the-shelf displays and cameras.
 
During the NSF SBIR I grant period, PIXELSIO developed methods which progressed from using 
dedicated screen area, to full-screen overlays that are not limited to solid colors. Most importantly, 
with the support of the NSF SBIR I grant, PIXELSIO Video Response Code technology is now 
compatible in software with ordinary 60Hz displays. The PIXELSIO Video Response Code technology 
can now be used in a wide range of higher layer applications without the technology risk and unknowns.
 
The resulting product will be packaged as a two-way communication system 
between the display and camera. We describe several applications which may have 
partners in the enterprise distribution ecosystem:
 
Retail: Retailers regularly leverage better and cleaner data as a result 
of more interaction between the end user and the enterprise system. PIXELSIO 
Video Response Code technology serves as a gateway for many of these 
interactions.  This can occur on the edges where paper receipts are no longer 
necessary and PIXELSIO Video Response Code technology enables pointing the 
camera at the checkout display and receiving a digital receipt. PIXELSIO Video 
Response Code can also enable understanding deep in the system stack where 
digital items such as gift cards and movie tickets that are sold directly off of a display.
 
Supply Chain: Planning and forecasting information is significantly tied 
down to the constantly changing effects of pricing, promotion and assortment 
changes.  Accessing this type of information can be time-consuming internally. 
PIXELSIO Video Response Code technology can enable access to the constantly 
changing data behind your supply chain. Point your camera at the internal 
display and be securely connected with the relevant sourcing information. 
Address verification features may be accessed by pointing the camera at a map 
with designated information.
 
P2P Health Records: Secure transfer of private data may be done between a 
personal phone and an ordinary display with a digital form. Once the form has been 
filled out, this information may be transferred from one device to another 
safely. This may be an add-on to existing display networks which are 
not fitted with any interactivity hardware.
 
Portal: Where visual real estate is primarily used for conveying the image of the 
company, rather than use a QR-Code to login, the user associates the visual logo 
with a prompt to participate within that environment.
 
Integrated Environments: PIXELSIO Video Response Code technology may serve 
as the unifying gateway for distinct sectors with displays as primary user interfaces. 
Active car dashboards may be integrated with advertisement displays used at a gas 
stations. This experience may be tied together with a suite of enterprise services for 
the car owner.
